content:
TITLE: Integrating marimo with FastAPI in Python DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates how to create a marimo ASGI app, integrate it with FastAPI, add middleware, and run the server. It includes setting up multiple marimo apps with different paths. SOURCE: https://github.com/marimo-team/marimo/blob/main/docs/guides/deploying/programmatically.md#2025-04-19_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` from typing import Annotated, Callable, Coroutine from fastapi.responses import HTMLResponse, RedirectResponse import marimo from fastapi import FastAPI, Form, Request, Response # Create a marimo asgi app server = ( marimo.create_asgi_app() .with_app(path="", root="./pages/index.py") .with_app(path="/dashboard", root="./pages/dashboard.py") .with_app(path="/sales", root="./pages/sales.py") ) # Create a FastAPI app app = FastAPI() app.add_middleware(auth_middleware) app.add_route("/login", my_login_route, methods=["POST"]) app.mount("/", server.build()) # Run the server if __name__ == "__main__": import uvicorn uvicorn.run(app, host="localhost", port=8000) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Installing marimo with pip (Minimal Dependencies) DESCRIPTION: Command to install marimo using pip with minimal dependencies. This is the standard installation method for most users. SOURCE: https://github.com/marimo-team/marimo/blob/main/docs/getting_started/installation.md#2025-04-19_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: bash CODE: ``` pip install marimo ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Defining Variables in Setup Cell - Python DESCRIPTION: Example showing how to properly define variables directly within a setup cell rather than referencing external definitions. SOURCE: https://github.com/marimo-team/marimo/blob/main/docs/guides/understanding_errors/setup.md#2025-04-19_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` image = "image.png" image ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Executing marimo notebooks as Python scripts DESCRIPTION: Command to execute a marimo notebook as a regular Python script from the command line. SOURCE: https://github.com/marimo-team/marimo/blob/main/README.md#2025-04-19_snippet_5 LANGUAGE: bash CODE: ``` python your_notebook.py ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Creating Dynamic UI Elements and Implementing Stack Layouts in Marimo DESCRIPTION: This code creates a UI demonstration of Marimo's stack layout capabilities. It defines functions to create box elements, UI controls for layout properties, and implements both horizontal and vertical stacks with configurable styling options. SOURCE: https://github.com/marimo-team/marimo/blob/main/docs/api/layouts/stacks.md#2025-04-19_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` @app.cell def __(): def create_box(num=1): box_size = 30 + num * 10 return mo.Html( f"
{str(num)}
" ) boxes = [create_box(i) for i in range(1, 5)] return @app.cell def __(): justify = mo.ui.dropdown( ["start", "center", "end", "space-between", "space-around"], value="space-between", label="justify", ) align = mo.ui.dropdown( ["start", "center", "end", "stretch"], value="center", label="align" ) gap = mo.ui.number(start=0, step=0.25, stop=2, value=0.25, label="gap") wrap = mo.ui.checkbox(label="wrap") return @app.cell def __(): horizontal = mo.hstack( boxes, align=align.value, justify=justify.value, gap=gap.value, wrap=wrap.value, ) vertical = mo.vstack( boxes, align=align.value, gap=gap.value, ) mo.vstack( [ mo.hstack([justify, align, gap], justify="center"), horizontal, mo.md("-----------------------------"), vertical, ], align="stretch", gap=1, ) return ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Anthropic Claude Chat Integration in Python DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates integration with Anthropic's Claude models. This example shows how to configure the chat UI with a Claude model, system message, and API key. SOURCE: https://github.com/marimo-team/marimo/blob/main/docs/api/inputs/chat.md#2025-04-19_snippet_7 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` import marimo as mo mo.ui.chat( mo.ai.llm.anthropic( "claude-3-5-sonnet-20240620", system_message="You are a helpful assistant.", api_key="sk-ant-...", ), show_configuration_controls=True ) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Creating Reactive Altair Chart with Cars Dataset DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates setting up a reactive scatter plot using Altair in marimo, including data fetching and visualization. The example shows how to create an interactive point chart displaying car statistics with color-coded origins. SOURCE: https://github.com/marimo-team/marimo/blob/main/docs/api/plotting.md#2025-04-19_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` @app.cell async def __(): import pandas as pd import pyodide import micropip import json await micropip.install('altair') import altair as alt return @app.cell def __(): cars = pd.DataFrame(json.loads( pyodide.http.open_url('https://vega.github.io/vega-datasets/data/cars.json').read() )) chart = mo.ui.altair_chart(alt.Chart(cars).mark_point().encode( x='Horsepower', y='Miles_per_Gallon', color='Origin' )) return @app.cell def __(): mo.vstack([chart, mo.ui.table(chart.value)]) return ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Loading and Displaying a Dataframe with Marimo's UI Element DESCRIPTION: This code demonstrates how to load a CSV file using pyodide's HTTP functionality and display it using Marimo's dataframe UI element. The element allows interactive manipulation of the dataframe with visual tools. SOURCE: https://github.com/marimo-team/marimo/blob/main/docs/api/inputs/dataframe.md#2025-04-19_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` @app.cell def __(): import pandas as pd import pyodide csv = pyodide.http.open_url("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/mwaskom/seaborn-data/master/iris.csv") df = pd.read_csv(csv) mo.ui.dataframe(df) return ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Connecting to custom databases in marimo DESCRIPTION: Examples of creating database connections using SQLAlchemy, SQLModel, and DuckDB in marimo for use in SQL cells. SOURCE: https://github.com/marimo-team/marimo/blob/main/docs/guides/working_with_data/sql.md#2025-04-19_snippet_6 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` import sqlalchemy import sqlmodel import duckdb # Create an in-memory SQLite database with SQLAlchemy sqlite_engine = sqlachemy.create_engine("sqlite:///:memory:") # Create a Postgres database with SQLModel postgres_engine = sqlmodel.create_engine("postgresql://username:password@server:port/database") # Create a DuckDB connection duckdb_conn = duckdb.connect("file.db") ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Implementing Todo List with State in Python DESCRIPTION: Creates a complete todo list application using mo.state to manage tasks, including adding, marking complete, and clearing completed tasks. SOURCE: https://github.com/marimo-team/marimo/blob/main/docs/guides/state.md#2025-04-19_snippet_4 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` import marimo as mo from dataclasses import dataclass @dataclass class Task: name: str done: bool = False get_tasks, set_tasks = mo.state([]) task_added, set_task_added = mo.state(False) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Creating Data Explorer with Iris Dataset in Python DESCRIPTION: Implements a data explorer UI using marimo's data_explorer component. The code loads the iris dataset from a remote CSV file using pyodide's HTTP capabilities and pandas, then displays it in an interactive data explorer interface. SOURCE: https://github.com/marimo-team/marimo/blob/main/docs/api/inputs/data_explorer.md#2025-04-19_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` @app.cell def __(): import pandas as pd import pyodide csv = pyodide.http.open_url("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/mwaskom/seaborn-data/master/iris.csv") df = pd.read_csv(csv) mo.ui.data_explorer(df) return ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Creating a Custom Counter Widget with AnyWidget (Python, JavaScript, CSS) DESCRIPTION: Illustrates how to create a custom AnyWidget for a counter button. Includes Python class definition, JavaScript rendering logic, and CSS styling. Demonstrates syncing state between Python and JavaScript. SOURCE: https://github.com/marimo-team/marimo/blob/main/docs/api/inputs/anywidget.md#2025-04-19_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` import anywidget import traitlets import marimo as mo class CounterWidget(anywidget.AnyWidget): # Widget front-end JavaScript code _esm = """ function render({ model, el }) { let getCount = () => model.get("count"); let button = document.createElement("button"); button.innerHTML = `count is ${getCount()}`; button.addEventListener("click", () => { model.set("count", getCount() + 1); model.save_changes(); }); model.on("change:count", () => { button.innerHTML = `count is ${getCount()}`; }); el.appendChild(button); } export default { render }; """ _css = """ button { padding: 5px !important; border-radius: 5px !important; background-color: #f0f0f0 !important; &:hover { background-color: lightblue !important; color: white !important; } } """ # Stateful property that can be accessed by JavaScript & Python count = traitlets.Int(0).tag(sync=True) widget = mo.ui.anywidget(CounterWidget()) # In another cell, you can access the widget's value widget.value # You can also access the widget's specific properties widget.count ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Querying files and databases in marimo SQL DESCRIPTION: Examples of querying different data sources including S3 buckets, CSV files, and Parquet files using SQL in marimo. SOURCE: https://github.com/marimo-team/marimo/blob/main/docs/guides/working_with_data/sql.md#2025-04-19_snippet_4 LANGUAGE: sql CODE: ``` -- or SELECT * FROM 's3://my-bucket/file.parquet'; -- or SELECT * FROM read_csv('path/to/example.csv'); -- or SELECT * FROM read_parquet('path/to/example.parquet'); ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Selectable Tables with Pandas DESCRIPTION: Shows how to create interactive, selectable tables using Pandas dataframes in Marimo. SOURCE: https://github.com/marimo-team/marimo/blob/main/docs/guides/working_with_data/dataframes.md#2025-04-19_snippet_4 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` # Cell 1 - display a dataframe import marimo as mo import pandas as pd df = pd.DataFrame({"a": [1, 2, 3], "b": [4, 5, 6]}) table = mo.ui.table(df, selection="multi") table ``` LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` # Cell 2 - display the selection table.value ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Creating File Upload Components with Marimo UI DESCRIPTION: This code creates two types of file upload components using Marimo UI and stacks them vertically. The first component is a button-style file uploader, and the second is an area-style file uploader that provides a larger drop area. SOURCE: https://github.com/marimo-team/marimo/blob/main/docs/api/inputs/file.md#2025-04-19_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` @app.cell def __(): mo.vstack([mo.ui.file(kind="button"), mo.ui.file(kind="area")]) return ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Displaying Slider with Its Current Value DESCRIPTION: Shows how to display a slider alongside its current value using horizontal stacking (hstack) and Markdown formatting. This creates a reactive UI that updates when the slider value changes. SOURCE: https://github.com/marimo-team/marimo/blob/main/docs/api/inputs/slider.md#2025-04-19_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` @app.cell def __(): mo.hstack([slider, mo.md(f"Has value: {slider.value}")]) return ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Listing marimo tutorials DESCRIPTION: Command to list all available marimo tutorials using the CLI. SOURCE: https://github.com/marimo-team/marimo/blob/main/docs/index.md#2025-04-19_snippet_8 LANGUAGE: bash CODE: ``` marimo tutorial --help ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Implementing Basic Marimo Carousel with Mixed Content DESCRIPTION: Shows how to create a carousel component using marimo that displays multiple content types including markdown headings, plain text, and images. The carousel is constructed using mo.carousel() and can contain markdown elements, strings, and image references. SOURCE: https://github.com/marimo-team/marimo/blob/main/docs/api/layouts/carousel.md#2025-04-19_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` @app.cell def __(): mo.carousel([ mo.md("# Introduction"), "By the marimo team", mo.md("## What is marimo?"), mo.md("![marimo moss ball](https://marimo.io/logo.png)"), mo.md("## Questions?"), ]) return ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Using Lazy Loading with Accordion Component in Marimo DESCRIPTION: This example demonstrates how to use mo.lazy() to defer the execution of an expensive function until an accordion is opened. The lazy component is configured to show a loading indicator while the function is executing. SOURCE: https://github.com/marimo-team/marimo/blob/main/docs/api/layouts/lazy.md#2025-04-19_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` @app.cell def __(): mo.accordion({ "Open me": mo.lazy(expensive_number, show_loading_indicator=True) }) return @app.cell def __(): import time import random def expensive_number(): time.sleep(1) num = random.randint(0, 100) return num return ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Implementing Data Editor in Marimo Python Notebook DESCRIPTION: This code snippet demonstrates how to create and use a data editor in a Marimo notebook. It initializes a pandas DataFrame, creates a data editor UI element, and displays the edited data. SOURCE: https://github.com/marimo-team/marimo/blob/main/docs/api/inputs/data_editor.md#2025-04-19_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` import marimo as mo import pandas as pd # Create a sample DataFrame df = pd.DataFrame({ "Name": ["Alice", "Bob", "Charlie"], "Age": [25, 30, 35], "City": ["New York", "San Francisco", "London"] }) # Create a data editor editor = mo.ui.data_editor(df) # Display the editor mo.md("## Data Editor") mo.hstack([editor]) # Display the edited data mo.md("## Edited Data") mo.table(editor.value) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Using mo.ui.refresh for Timer-Based Cell Execution in Python DESCRIPTION: This example demonstrates how to use mo.ui.refresh to automatically run a cell on a timer in Marimo. The refresh utility allows setting intervals for cell execution, which is useful for monitoring data that changes over time or creating dynamic visualizations that update automatically. SOURCE: https://github.com/marimo-team/marimo/blob/main/docs/examples/running_cells/refresh.md#2025-04-19_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` # Refresh cells on a timer Use [`mo.ui.refresh`][marimo.ui.refresh] to run a cell on a timer ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Implementing Number Input Widget with Marimo DESCRIPTION: Creates an interactive number input widget with a range of 1-20 and displays its current value. Uses mo.ui.number for input creation and mo.hstack for horizontal layout of components. SOURCE: https://github.com/marimo-team/marimo/blob/main/docs/api/inputs/number.md#2025-04-19_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` @app.cell def __(): number = mo.ui.number(start=1, stop=20, label="Number") return @app.cell def __(): mo.hstack([number, mo.md(f"Has value: {number.value}")]) return ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Setting up a marimo App with Navigation and Routing DESCRIPTION: This code demonstrates a complete marimo application with sidebar navigation and client-side routing. It creates a sidebar with links to different pages, implements route handlers for different URL paths, and includes a catch-all route for handling undefined paths. SOURCE: https://github.com/marimo-team/marimo/blob/main/docs/api/layouts/routes.md#2025-04-19_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` import marimo app = marimo.App() @app.cell def __(): import marimo as mo return @app.cell def __(): mo.sidebar( [ mo.md("# marimo"), mo.nav_menu( { "#/": f"{mo.icon('lucide:home')} Home", "#/about": f"{mo.icon('lucide:user')} About", "#/contact": f"{mo.icon('lucide:phone')} Contact", "Links": { "https://twitter.com/marimo_io": "Twitter", "https://github.com/marimo-team/marimo": "GitHub", }, }, orientation="vertical", ), ] ) return @app.cell def __(): mo.routes({ "#/": mo.md("# Home"), "#/about": mo.md("# About"), "#/contact": mo.md("# Contact"), mo.routes.CATCH_ALL: mo.md("# Home"), }) return ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Installing marimo via pip and running the intro tutorial DESCRIPTION: Basic installation command for marimo using pip, followed by launching the introduction tutorial. This is the quickest way to get started with marimo. SOURCE: https://github.com/marimo-team/marimo/blob/main/README.md#2025-04-19_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` pip install marimo && marimo tutorial intro ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Customizing Altair Selection Behavior DESCRIPTION: Shows how to disable automatic selection and implement custom selection behavior using interval selection in Altair charts. SOURCE: https://github.com/marimo-team/marimo/blob/main/docs/guides/working_with_data/plotting.md#2025-04-19_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` brush = alt.selection_interval(encodings=["x"]) _chart = ( alt.Chart(traces, height=150) .mark_line() .encode(x="index:Q", y="value:Q", color="traces:N") .add_params(brush) # add the selection to the chart ) chart = mo.ui.altair_chart( _chart, # disable automatic selection chart_selection=False, legend_selection=False ) chart # You can now access chart.value to get the selected data ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Creating Interactive Plotly Chart DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates creating a reactive scatter plot using Plotly and marimo, including setup and data display. SOURCE: https://github.com/marimo-team/marimo/blob/main/docs/guides/working_with_data/plotting.md#2025-04-19_snippet_4 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` @app.cell(hide_code=True) async def __(): import micropip await micropip.install("pandas") await micropip.install("plotly") import plotly.express as px return micropip, px @app.cell def __(px): plot = mo.ui.plotly( px.scatter(x=[0, 1, 4, 9, 16], y=[0, 1, 2, 3, 4], width=600, height=300) ) plot return plot @app.cell def __(plot): plot.value return ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Creating and Displaying Multiselect Component in Marimo DESCRIPTION: Creates a multiselect dropdown with fruit options and displays it alongside its selected value using horizontal stack layout. The component allows multiple selections from a predefined list of options. SOURCE: https://github.com/marimo-team/marimo/blob/main/docs/api/inputs/multiselect.md#2025-04-19_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` @app.cell def __(): options = ["Apples", "Oranges", "Pears"] multiselect = mo.ui.multiselect(options=options) return @app.cell def __(): mo.hstack([multiselect, mo.md(f"Has value: {multiselect.value}")]) return ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Exporting Marimo Notebook as Readonly WASM-powered HTML DESCRIPTION: Command to export a Marimo notebook as a readonly WebAssembly-powered HTML file. This creates a self-contained, executable notebook that can be run in a web browser. SOURCE: https://github.com/marimo-team/marimo/blob/main/docs/guides/publishing/cloudflare_pages.md#2025-04-19_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: bash CODE: ``` marimo export html-wasm notebook.py -o output_dir --mode run ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Implementing Custom Authentication with FastAPI in marimo DESCRIPTION: This Python code snippet shows how to create a marimo ASGI app, integrate it with FastAPI, and add custom authentication middleware. It includes setting up routes for multiple marimo apps and a login endpoint. SOURCE: https://github.com/marimo-team/marimo/blob/main/docs/guides/deploying/authentication.md#2025-04-19_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` from typing import Annotated, Callable, Coroutine from fastapi.responses import HTMLResponse, RedirectResponse import marimo from fastapi import FastAPI, Form, Request, Response # Custom auth middleware and login page from my_auth_module import auth_middleware, my_login_route # Create a marimo asgi app server = ( marimo.create_asgi_app() .with_app(path="", root="./pages/index.py") .with_app(path="/dashboard", root="./pages/dashboard.py") .with_app(path="/sales", root="./pages/sales.py") ) # Create a FastAPI app app = FastAPI() app.add_middleware(auth_middleware) app.add_route("/login", my_login_route, methods=["POST"]) app.mount("/", server.build()) # Run the server if __name__ == "__main__": import uvicorn uvicorn.run(app, host="localhost", port=8000) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Using Progress Bar in Marimo for Iteration Visualization DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates how to use marimo's progress_bar function to visualize iteration progress, similar to tqdm. This component displays a progress bar while processing collections or loading data. SOURCE: https://github.com/marimo-team/marimo/blob/main/docs/api/status.md#2025-04-19_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` marimo.status.progress_bar ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Interactive Dataframe Transformation with Pandas DESCRIPTION: Example of using Marimo's UI components to create and transform Pandas dataframes interactively. SOURCE: https://github.com/marimo-team/marimo/blob/main/docs/guides/working_with_data/dataframes.md#2025-04-19_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` # Cell 1 import marimo as mo import pandas as pd df = pd.DataFrame({"person": ["Alice", "Bob", "Charlie"], "age": [20, 30, 40]}) transformed_df = mo.ui.dataframe(df) transformed_df ``` LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` # Cell 2 # transformed_df.value holds the transformed dataframe transformed_df.value ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Using Tabs Component in Marimo UI (Python) DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates how to create and use the Tabs component in Marimo UI. The example shows implementation of tabbed interfaces with different tab styles and content types, including the ability to set the active tab programmatically. SOURCE: https://github.com/marimo-team/marimo/blob/main/docs/api/inputs/tabs.md#2025-04-19_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` /// marimo-embed-file size: large mode: edit filepath: examples/ui/tabs.py /// ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Implementing Counter UI with State in Python DESCRIPTION: Creates an interactive counter with increment and decrement buttons using mo.state and mo.ui components. SOURCE: https://github.com/marimo-team/marimo/blob/main/docs/guides/state.md#2025-04-19_snippet_3 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` import marimo as mo get_counter, set_counter = mo.state(0) increment = mo.ui.button( label="increment", on_change=lambda _: set_counter(lambda v: v + 1), ) decrement = mo.ui.button( label="decrement", on_change=lambda _: set_counter(lambda v: v - 1), ) mo.hstack([increment, decrement], justify="center") ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Displaying DataFrames - Streamlit vs Marimo DESCRIPTION: Shows how to display dataframes in both frameworks, highlighting marimo's automatic display feature. SOURCE: https://github.com/marimo-team/marimo/blob/main/docs/guides/coming_from/streamlit.md#2025-04-19_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` st.dataframe(df) ``` LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` df # Last expression in a cell is automatically displayed ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Creating and Displaying a Checkbox in Marimo DESCRIPTION: This example demonstrates how to create a checkbox with a label and display its current value in a horizontal stack layout. The code uses mo.ui.checkbox to create the UI element and mo.hstack to arrange components horizontally. SOURCE: https://github.com/marimo-team/marimo/blob/main/docs/api/inputs/checkbox.md#2025-04-19_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` @app.cell def __(): checkbox = mo.ui.checkbox(label="check me") return @app.cell def __(): mo.hstack([checkbox, mo.md(f"Has value: {checkbox.value}")]) return ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Creating and Displaying Dictionary UI Component in Marimo DESCRIPTION: This code creates a dictionary UI component with text inputs for first name, last name, and email. It then displays the dictionary component alongside its value using a horizontal stack layout. SOURCE: https://github.com/marimo-team/marimo/blob/main/docs/api/inputs/dictionary.md#2025-04-19_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` @app.cell def __(): first_name = mo.ui.text(placeholder="First name") last_name = mo.ui.text(placeholder="Last name") email = mo.ui.text(placeholder="Email", kind="email") dictionary = mo.ui.dictionary( { "First name": first_name, "Last name": last_name, "Email": email, } ) return @app.cell def __(): mo.hstack( [dictionary, dictionary.value], justify="space-between" ) return ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Creating a Dockerfile for Marimo Application Deployment DESCRIPTION: This Dockerfile sets up a Python environment, installs dependencies using uv, copies the application files, and configures the container to run a Marimo app. It uses a non-root user for improved security and exposes port 8080 for access. SOURCE: https://github.com/marimo-team/marimo/blob/main/docs/guides/deploying/deploying_docker.md#2025-04-19_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: Dockerfile CODE: ``` # syntax=docker/dockerfile:1.4 # Choose a python version that you know works with your application FROM python:3.11-slim # Install uv for fast package management COPY --from=ghcr.io/astral-sh/uv:0.4.20 /uv /bin/uv ENV UV_SYSTEM_PYTHON=1 WORKDIR /app # Copy requirements file COPY --link requirements.txt . # Install the requirements using uv RUN uv pip install -r requirements.txt # Copy application files COPY --link app.py . # Uncomment the following line if you need to copy additional files # COPY --link . . EXPOSE 8080 # Create a non-root user and switch to it RUN useradd -m app_user USER app_user CMD [ "marimo", "run", "app.py", "--host", "0.0.0.0", "-p", "8080" ] ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Interactive Run Button Implementation DESCRIPTION: Shows how to create an interactive run button with cell dependencies in Marimo SOURCE: https://github.com/marimo-team/marimo/blob/main/docs/guides/coming_from/jupyter.md#2025-04-19_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` @app.cell def __(): run_button = mo.ui.run_button() run_button return @app.cell def __(): mo.stop(not run_button.value, mo.md("Click ðŸ‘† to run this cell")) mo.md("You clicked the button! ðŸŽ‰") return ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: OpenAI GPT Chat Implementation in Python DESCRIPTION: Shows how to use Marimo's built-in OpenAI integration to create a chat interface with GPT models. This example sets a system message and enables configuration controls for the model parameters. SOURCE: https://github.com/marimo-team/marimo/blob/main/docs/api/inputs/chat.md#2025-04-19_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` import marimo as mo chat = mo.ui.chat( mo.ai.llm.openai( "gpt-4", system_message="You are a helpful assistant.", ), show_configuration_controls=True ) chat ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Basic Echo Model Chat UI Implementation in Python DESCRIPTION: A simple example showing how to create a chat UI with a custom echo model that responds with the user's message. It demonstrates the basic pattern for implementing a chat interface with predefined prompts. SOURCE: https://github.com/marimo-team/marimo/blob/main/docs/api/inputs/chat.md#2025-04-19_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` import marimo as mo def echo_model(messages, config): return f"Echo: {messages[-1].content}" chat = mo.ui.chat(echo_model, prompts=["Hello", "How are you?"]) chat ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Chat UI with File Attachment Support in Python DESCRIPTION: Shows how to configure the chat UI to accept file attachments. This example demonstrates limiting attachment types to specific MIME types (PNG and JPEG images) but also shows how to allow any attachment type. SOURCE: https://github.com/marimo-team/marimo/blob/main/docs/api/inputs/chat.md#2025-04-19_snippet_5 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` mo.ui.chat( rag_model, allow_attachments=["image/png", "image/jpeg"], # or True for any attachment type # allow_attachments=True, ) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Jupyter Export Commands DESCRIPTION: Commands for exporting to Jupyter notebook format and converting to various formats using nbconvert. SOURCE: https://github.com/marimo-team/marimo/blob/main/docs/guides/exporting.md#2025-04-19_snippet_5 LANGUAGE: bash CODE: ``` marimo export ipynb notebook.py -o notebook.ipynb NOTEBOOK=notebook.ipynb # Convert to PDF using nbconvert uvx --with nbconvert --from jupyter-core jupyter nbconvert --to pdf $NOTEBOOK # Convert to web PDF uvx --with "nbconvert[webpdf]" --from jupyter-core jupyter nbconvert --to webpdf $NOTEBOOK --allow-chromium-download # Convert to slides uvx --with nbconvert --from jupyter-core jupyter nbconvert --to slides $NOTEBOOK # Convert to rst with nbconvert uvx --with nbconvert --from jupyter-core jupyter nbconvert --to rst $NOTEBOOK # Generate PNG/PDF of specific cells using nbconvert uvx --with nbconvert --with jupyter --from jupyter-core jupyter nbconvert --to pdf --execute --stdout $NOTEBOOK \ --TemplateExporter.exclude_input=True # Use nbconvert programmatically for more control uv run --with nbconvert python -c " from nbconvert import PDFExporter import nbformat nb = nbformat.read('$NOTEBOOK', as_version=4) pdf_exporter = PDFExporter() pdf_data, resources = pdf_exporter.from_notebook_node(nb) with open('notebook.pdf', 'wb') as f: f.write(pdf_data) " ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Implementing _mime_() Method for JSON Display in Python DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to implement a _mime_() method for a MyJSONObject class. The method returns a tuple with the MIME type 'application/json' and the JSON-encoded data. SOURCE: https://github.com/marimo-team/marimo/blob/main/docs/guides/integrating_with_marimo/displaying_objects.md#2025-04-19_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` import json class MyJSONObject(object): def __init__(self, data: dict[str, object]) -> None: self.data = data def _mime_(self) -> tuple[str, str]: return ("application/json", json.dumps(self.data)) MyJSONObject({"hello": "world"}) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Displaying Remote Image with Marimo Image Component DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates rendering an image from a remote URL using Marimo's image component with custom dimensions and rounded corners. The example uses a sample owl image from Pexels and sets specific width and height parameters along with border radius styling. SOURCE: https://github.com/marimo-team/marimo/blob/main/docs/api/media/image.md#2025-04-19_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` @app.cell def __(): _src = ( "https://images.pexels.com/photos/86596/owl-bird-eyes-eagle-owl-86596.jpeg" ) mo.image(src=_src, width="180px", height="180px", rounded=True) return ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Groq LLM Chat Integration in Python DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates integration with Groq's LLMs. This example configures the chat UI with a Llama model from Groq, including system message and API key settings. SOURCE: https://github.com/marimo-team/marimo/blob/main/docs/api/inputs/chat.md#2025-04-19_snippet_9 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` import marimo as mo mo.ui.chat( mo.ai.llm.groq( "llama-3.1-70b-versatile", system_message="You are a helpful assistant.", api_key="gsk-...", ), show_configuration_controls=True ) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Creating and Using a Switch Component in Marimo DESCRIPTION: This code demonstrates how to create a switch component with a label and access its value. The example creates a switch labeled 'do not disturb' and then displays the switch alongside its current value in a horizontal stack layout. SOURCE: https://github.com/marimo-team/marimo/blob/main/docs/api/inputs/switch.md#2025-04-19_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` @app.cell def __(): switch = mo.ui.switch(label="do not disturb") return @app.cell def __(): mo.hstack([switch, mo.md(f"Has value: {switch.value}")]) return ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: In-Memory Caching with mo.cache Decorator DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates using mo.cache as a decorator to cache expensive function results in memory based on input parameters. SOURCE: https://github.com/marimo-team/marimo/blob/main/docs/guides/expensive_notebooks.md#2025-04-19_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` import marimo as mo @mo.cache def compute_predictions(problem_parameters): # do some expensive computations and return a value ... ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Creating a SQL cell in marimo DESCRIPTION: Example of creating a SQL cell in marimo, which is syntactic sugar for Python code. It demonstrates how to query a table and store the result in a DataFrame. SOURCE: https://github.com/marimo-team/marimo/blob/main/docs/guides/working_with_data/sql.md#2025-04-19_snippet_3 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` output_df = mo.sql(f"SELECT * FROM my_table LIMIT {max_rows.value}") ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Creating a Sidebar with Navigation Menu in marimo (Python) DESCRIPTION: This code creates a sidebar using marimo's UI components. It includes a title, a vertical navigation menu with internal links and icons, and a submenu for external links. The sidebar is configured using the mo.sidebar() function and populated with markdown and a navigation menu. SOURCE: https://github.com/marimo-team/marimo/blob/main/docs/api/layouts/sidebar.md#2025-04-19_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` @app.cell def __(): mo.sidebar( [ mo.md("# marimo"), mo.nav_menu( { "#/home": f"{mo.icon('lucide:home')} Home", "#/about": f"{mo.icon('lucide:user')} About", "#/contact": f"{mo.icon('lucide:phone')} Contact", "Links": { "https://twitter.com/marimo_io": "Twitter", "https://github.com/marimo-team/marimo": "GitHub", }, }, orientation="vertical", ), ] ) return ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Creating and Displaying Text Area Form in Marimo DESCRIPTION: This code creates a text area form using Marimo's UI components and displays it along with its current value. The form is created with a placeholder text and embedded in a vertical stack layout with a markdown component showing its value. SOURCE: https://github.com/marimo-team/marimo/blob/main/docs/api/inputs/form.md#2025-04-19_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` @app.cell def __(): form = mo.ui.text_area(placeholder="...").form() return @app.cell def __(): mo.vstack([form, mo.md(f"Has value: {form.value}")]) return ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Implementing Code Editor Component in Python with Marimo DESCRIPTION: Example demonstrating how to use the Code Editor component from Marimo's UI toolkit. The code showcases creating a code editor with Python syntax highlighting, capturing user inputs, and displaying the results. SOURCE: https://github.com/marimo-team/marimo/blob/main/docs/api/inputs/code_editor.md#2025-04-19_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` # examples/ui/code_editor.py import marimo as mo @mo.cell def __(): code = mo.ui.code("print('Hello, world!')\nprint(1 + 1)", language="python") return code @mo.cell def __(): mo.md(f"You entered:\n```python\n{code.value}\n```") @mo.cell def __(): run_btn = mo.ui.button(label="Run") return run_btn @mo.cell def __(): if run_btn.value: compiled = compile(code.value, "", "exec") local_vars = {} exec(compiled, globals(), local_vars) return local_vars ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Creating a Basic Numeric Slider in Marimo DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates how to create a basic slider component with a numeric range from 1 to 20 and an initial value of 3. The slider includes a label for better user experience. SOURCE: https://github.com/marimo-team/marimo/blob/main/docs/api/inputs/slider.md#2025-04-19_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` @app.cell def __(): slider = mo.ui.slider(start=1, stop=20, label="Slider", value=3) return ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Creating a Slider with Marimo UI in Python DESCRIPTION: This snippet shows how to create an interactive slider using Marimo's UI components. The slider is set with a range from 0 to 10 and an initial value of 2. SOURCE: https://github.com/marimo-team/marimo/blob/main/docs/guides/island_example.md#2025-04-19_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: Python CODE: ``` slider = mo.ui.slider(0, 10,value=2); slider ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Creating and Displaying a Paginated Table in Marimo with The Office Characters Data DESCRIPTION: This code demonstrates how to create and work with tables in Marimo. It defines a dataset of characters from The Office TV show, creates a paginated table using mo.ui.table, and displays both the table and its value using mo.vstack. The table component supports pagination for handling larger datasets. SOURCE: https://github.com/marimo-team/marimo/blob/main/docs/api/inputs/table.md#2025-04-19_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` @app.cell def __(): table = mo.ui.table(data=office_characters, pagination=True) return @app.cell def __(): mo.vstack([table, table.value]) return @app.cell def __(): office_characters = [ {"first_name": "Michael", "last_name": "Scott"}, {"first_name": "Jim", "last_name": "Halpert"}, {"first_name": "Pam", "last_name": "Beesly"}, {"first_name": "Dwight", "last_name": "Schrute"}, {"first_name": "Angela", "last_name": "Martin"}, {"first_name": "Kevin", "last_name": "Malone"}, {"first_name": "Oscar", "last_name": "Martinez"}, {"first_name": "Stanley", "last_name": "Hudson"}, {"first_name": "Phyllis", "last_name": "Vance"}, {"first_name": "Meredith", "last_name": "Palmer"}, {"first_name": "Creed", "last_name": "Bratton"}, {"first_name": "Ryan", "last_name": "Howard"}, {"first_name": "Kelly", "last_name": "Kapoor"}, {"first_name": "Toby", "last_name": "Flenderson"}, {"first_name": "Darryl", "last_name": "Philbin"}, {"first_name": "Erin", "last_name": "Hannon"}, {"first_name": "Andy", "last_name": "Bernard"}, {"first_name": "Jan", "last_name": "Levinson"}, {"first_name": "David", "last_name": "Wallace"}, {"first_name": "Holly", "last_name": "Flax"}, ] return ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Implementing Progress Bar in Marimo (Python) DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to create and update a progress bar in Marimo. It uses the mo.ui.progress() function to initialize the bar, updates it within a loop simulating work, and finally displays the completed progress. SOURCE: https://github.com/marimo-team/marimo/blob/main/docs/examples/outputs/progress_bar.md#2025-04-19_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: Python CODE: ``` import marimo as mo import time progress = mo.ui.progress(0) mo.md(f"Progress: {progress}") for i in range(100): time.sleep(0.05) # Simulate work progress.update((i + 1) / 100) mo.md("**Done!**") ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Exporting marimo Notebook to HTML (Bash) DESCRIPTION: Shows how to export a marimo notebook to HTML format with command-line arguments. This is useful for sharing static versions of notebooks with outputs. SOURCE: https://github.com/marimo-team/marimo/blob/main/docs/guides/coming_from/papermill.md#2025-04-19_snippet_6 LANGUAGE: bash CODE: ``` marimo export html notebook.py -o notebook.html -- -arg1 foo --arg2 bar ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Basic Altair Chart Example DESCRIPTION: Simple example showing how to create a reactive Altair scatter plot with cars dataset, including basic encoding and visualization setup. SOURCE: https://github.com/marimo-team/marimo/blob/main/docs/guides/working_with_data/plotting.md#2025-04-19_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` import marimo as mo import altair as alt import vega_datasets # Load some data cars = vega_datasets.data.cars() # Create an Altair chart chart = alt.Chart(cars).mark_point().encode( x='Horsepower', # Encoding along the x-axis y='Miles_per_Gallon', # Encoding along the y-axis color='Origin', # Category encoding by color ) # Make it reactive âš¡ chart = mo.ui.altair_chart(chart) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Creating a Run Button in Marimo DESCRIPTION: Create a run button that triggers computation when clicked. This is useful for controlling when specific calculations are performed. SOURCE: https://github.com/marimo-team/marimo/blob/main/docs/recipes.md#2025-04-19_snippet_17 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` button = mo.ui.run_button() button ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Connecting to ClickHouse using chDB DESCRIPTION: Example of creating a ClickHouse connection using chDB library in marimo for embedded connections, with various connection string formats. SOURCE: https://github.com/marimo-team/marimo/blob/main/docs/guides/working_with_data/sql.md#2025-04-19_snippet_8 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` import chdb connection = chdb.connect(":memory:") # Supported formats with examples: ":memory:" # In-memory database "test.db" # Relative path "file:test.db" # Explicit file protocol "/path/to/test.db" # Absolute path "file:/path/to/test.db" # Absolute path with protocol "file:test.db?param1=value1¶m2=value2" # With query parameters "file::memory:?verbose&log-level=test" # In-memory with parameters "///path/to/test.db?param1=value1" # Triple slash absolute path ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Implementing Persistent Caching for Long-Running Computations in Python DESCRIPTION: This code snippet demonstrates how to use mo.persistent_cache to cache the results of a long-running computation. It includes a function that simulates a time-consuming process and shows how to cache and retrieve its results. SOURCE: https://github.com/marimo-team/marimo/blob/main/docs/examples/running_cells/persistent_cache.md#2025-04-19_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` import marimo as mo import time @mo.persist def expensive_computation(n): """Simulate a long-running computation.""" time.sleep(5) # Simulate a 5-second computation return n ** 2 # First run: This will take about 5 seconds result = expensive_computation(10) mo.md(f"Result: {result}") # Second run: This will be instant, as the result is cached result = expensive_computation(10) mo.md(f"Result (from cache): {result}") # Different input: This will take about 5 seconds again result = expensive_computation(20) mo.md(f"Result for new input: {result}") ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Displaying UI Slider in Markdown DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates how to create a slider UI element and embed it within markdown text using Python f-strings. The slider is assigned to a global variable to enable interactive functionality. SOURCE: https://github.com/marimo-team/marimo/blob/main/docs/guides/interactivity.md#2025-04-19_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` slider = mo.ui.slider(1, 10) mo.md(f"Choose a value: {slider}") ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Interactive BigQuery Data Explorer DESCRIPTION: Python code demonstrating how to create an interactive BigQuery data explorer using marimo UI components. Includes dataset listing, table selection, and data preview functionality. SOURCE: https://github.com/marimo-team/marimo/blob/main/docs/integrations/google_cloud_bigquery.md#2025-04-19_snippet_3 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` # Cell 1 - Load libraries import marimo as mo from google.cloud import bigquery # Cell 2 - Load datasets client = bigquery.Client() datasets = list(client.list_datasets()) # Cell 3 - Select dataset selected_dataset = mo.ui.dropdown( label="Select dataset", options=[d.dataset_id for d in datasets] ) selected_dataset # Cell 4 - Load tables dataset = client.dataset(selected_dataset.value) tables = list(client.list_tables(dataset)) selected_table = mo.ui.dropdown( label="Select table", options=[t.table_id for t in tables] ) selected_table # Cell 5 - Load table data results = client.list_rows(dataset.table(selected_table.value), max_results=10) mo.ui.table(results.to_dataframe(), selection=None) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Creating Interactive Scatter Plot with Marimo DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates basic reactivity in marimo by creating an interactive scatter plot that updates based on a slider value. Shows how to create UI elements and handle automatic re-execution of dependent cells. SOURCE: https://github.com/marimo-team/marimo/blob/main/tests/_server/ai/snapshots/chat_system_prompts.txt#2025-04-19_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` import marimo as mo import matplotlib.pyplot as plt import numpy as np # Create a slider and display it n_points = mo.ui.slider(10, 100, value=50, label="Number of points") n_points # Display the slider # Generate random data based on slider value # This cell automatically re-executes when n_points.value changes x = np.random.rand(n_points.value) y = np.random.rand(n_points.value) plt.figure(figsize=(8, 6)) plt.scatter(x, y, alpha=0.7) plt.title(f"Scatter plot with {n_points.value} points") plt.xlabel("X axis") plt.ylabel("Y axis") plt.gca() # Return the current axes to display the plot ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Google AI Gemini Chat Integration in Python DESCRIPTION: Shows how to integrate Google's Gemini models with the chat UI. This example configures the chat with a Gemini model, system message, and API key. SOURCE: https://github.com/marimo-team/marimo/blob/main/docs/api/inputs/chat.md#2025-04-19_snippet_8 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` import marimo as mo mo.ui.chat( mo.ai.llm.google( "gemini-1.5-pro-latest", system_message="You are a helpful assistant.", api_key="AI..", ), show_configuration_controls=True ) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Configuring Nginx for Marimo Reverse Proxy DESCRIPTION: This Nginx server block configuration sets up a reverse proxy for a Marimo application. It includes necessary headers, WebSocket support, and an optional static file serving location. SOURCE: https://github.com/marimo-team/marimo/blob/main/docs/guides/deploying/deploying_nginx.md#2025-04-19_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: nginx CODE: ``` server { server_name your-domain.com; location / { proxy_set_header Host $host; proxy_set_header X-Real-IP $remote_addr; proxy_set_header X-Forwarded-For $proxy_add_x_forwarded_for; proxy_set_header X-Forwarded-Proto $scheme; proxy_pass http://127.0.0.1:2718; # Required for WebSocket support proxy_http_version 1.1; proxy_set_header Upgrade $http_upgrade; proxy_set_header Connection "upgrade"; proxy_read_timeout 600; } # Optional: Serve static files location /static/ { alias /path/to/your/static/files/; } } ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Persistent Disk Caching with Context Manager DESCRIPTION: Shows how to use mo.persistent_cache as a context manager to cache computation results to disk. SOURCE: https://github.com/marimo-team/marimo/blob/main/docs/guides/expensive_notebooks.md#2025-04-19_snippet_5 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` import marimo as mo with mo.persistent_cache(name="my_cache"): # This block of code and its computed variables will be cached to disk # the first time it's run. The next time it's run, `predictions`` # will be loaded from disk. predictions = compute_predictions(problem_parameters) ... ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Creating Interactive Button Stack with State Management DESCRIPTION: Shows how to create a horizontal stack of buttons with click handlers using mo.ui.array and state management. SOURCE: https://github.com/marimo-team/marimo/blob/main/docs/recipes.md#2025-04-19_snippet_10 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` import random # Create a state object that will store the index of the # clicked button get_state, set_state = mo.state(None) # Create an mo.ui.array of buttons - a regular Python list won't work. buttons = mo.ui.array( [ mo.ui.button( label="button " + str(i), on_change=lambda v, i=i: set_state(i) ) for i in range(random.randint(2, 5)) ] ) mo.hstack(buttons) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Creating a Form with Pre-populated Fields in Marimo DESCRIPTION: Create a form with text inputs that are pre-populated based on the selected example from the dropdown. The form includes a submit button. SOURCE: https://github.com/marimo-team/marimo/blob/main/docs/recipes.md#2025-04-19_snippet_15 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` form = ( mo.md( """ ### Your form {t1} {t2} """ ) .batch( t1=mo.ui.text(label="enter text", value=examples.value.get("t1", "")), t2=mo.ui.text(label="more text", value=examples.value.get("t2", "")), ) .form( submit_button_label="go" ) ) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Interactive Run Button Implementation with Marimo DESCRIPTION: Shows how to create an interactive run button UI element and use it to control cell execution with mo.stop. SOURCE: https://github.com/marimo-team/marimo/blob/main/docs/guides/expensive_notebooks.md#2025-04-19_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` @app.cell def __(): run_button = mo.ui.run_button() run_button return @app.cell def __(): mo.stop(not run_button.value, mo.md("Click ðŸ‘† to run this cell")) mo.md("You clicked the button! ðŸŽ‰") return ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Implementing Single Date Input in Marimo DESCRIPTION: Creates a single date picker component and displays its selected value. Uses mo.ui.date for input and mo.hstack for horizontal layout of components. SOURCE: https://github.com/marimo-team/marimo/blob/main/docs/api/inputs/dates.md#2025-04-19_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` @app.cell def __(): date = mo.ui.date(label="Start Date") return @app.cell def __(): mo.hstack([date, mo.md(f"Has value: {date.value}")]) return ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Installing and Running Marimo Example Notebooks DESCRIPTION: Command-line instructions for installing Marimo and running example notebooks. Includes the option to use the --sandbox flag for isolated virtual environments with automatic dependency installation. SOURCE: https://github.com/marimo-team/marimo/blob/main/examples/ai/tools/README.md#2025-04-19_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: shell CODE: ``` marimo edit --sandbox ``` LANGUAGE: shell CODE: ``` marimo edit ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Creating a Hierarchical Tree Display with Marimo in Python DESCRIPTION: This code snippet demonstrates how to use the Marimo tree component to create a hierarchical display of elements. It includes a mix of simple entries, nested structures, and an interactive UI slider component. The tree is labeled for clarity. SOURCE: https://github.com/marimo-team/marimo/blob/main/docs/api/layouts/tree.md#2025-04-19_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` @app.cell def __(): mo.tree( ["entry", "another entry", {"key": [0, mo.ui.slider(1, 10, value=5), 2]}], label="A tree of elements.", ) return ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Creating a Slider UI Component with Marimo in Python DESCRIPTION: This code creates a slider UI component using Marimo. The slider has a range from 0 to 10, allowing users to select a value within this range. SOURCE: https://github.com/marimo-team/marimo/blob/main/tests/_cli/snapshots/script.txt#2025-04-19_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: Python CODE: ``` slider = mo.ui.slider(0, 10) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Creating Accordion Components in Marimo DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates how to create accordion components with Marimo to organize content into collapsible sections. The example shows both simple and nested accordion usage with customization options like setting default opened/closed states. SOURCE: https://github.com/marimo-team/marimo/blob/main/docs/api/layouts/accordion.md#2025-04-19_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` import marimo as mo # Basic accordion usage mo.accordion( { "First section": mo.md("Some content in the first section"), "Second section": mo.md("Some content in the second section"), } ) # Accordion with nested content and styling mo.accordion( { "Simple text": "Just some text", "Markdown": mo.md("**Bold** and *italic*"), "Multiple elements": mo.vstack( [ mo.md("## This is a header"), mo.md("This is some text"), mo.callout("This is a callout", kind="info"), ] ), "Nested accordion": mo.accordion( { "Nested section 1": "Content 1", "Nested section 2": "Content 2", } ), } ) # Accordion with default opened sections mo.accordion( { "Default closed": "This section starts closed", "Default open": "This section starts open", }, open_ids=["Default open"], ) # Accordion with all sections initially open mo.accordion( { "Section 1": "Content 1", "Section 2": "Content 2", "Section 3": "Content 3", }, start_open=True, ) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Configuring Custom LLM Provider for Code Completion DESCRIPTION: Configuration for setting up a custom LLM provider for code completion. Includes settings for API key, model name, and base URL endpoint. Can be used with various providers including OpenAI, Anthropic, Google AI, or local models. SOURCE: https://github.com/marimo-team/marimo/blob/main/docs/guides/editor_features/ai_completion.md#2025-04-19_snippet_11 LANGUAGE: toml CODE: ``` [completion] copilot = "custom" api_key = "your-llm-api-key" model = "your-llm-model-name" base_url = "http://127.0.0.1:11434/v1" # or https://your-llm-api-endpoint.com ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Creating Metric Cards with Marimo Stats DESCRIPTION: Shows how to create multiple stat components displaying business metrics like active users, revenue and conversion rates. Each stat includes a value, label, caption showing change, and trend direction. The stats are arranged horizontally using mo.hstack with center justification. SOURCE: https://github.com/marimo-team/marimo/blob/main/docs/api/layouts/stat.md#2025-04-19_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` @app.cell def __(): active_users = mo.stat( value="1.2M", label="Active Users", caption="12k from last month", direction="increase" ) revenue = mo.stat( value="$4.5M", label="Revenue", caption="8k from last quarter", direction="increase" ) conversion = mo.stat( value="3.8", label="Conversion Rate", caption="0.5 from last week", direction="decrease", ) mo.hstack([active_users, revenue, conversion], justify="center", gap="2rem") return ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Creating a Logarithmic Slider with NumPy DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates creating a logarithmic slider using NumPy's logspace function to generate custom steps. This provides a slider that operates on a logarithmic scale from 10^-2 to 10^2 with 101 discrete steps. SOURCE: https://github.com/marimo-team/marimo/blob/main/docs/api/inputs/slider.md#2025-04-19_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` @app.cell def __(): # You can also use steps to create a slider on a custom range log_slider = mo.ui.slider(steps=np.logspace(-2, 2, 101), label="Logarithmic Slider", value=1) return ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Loading Dynamic Directories in marimo with Python DESCRIPTION: Shows how to create a marimo server that dynamically loads notebooks from a directory. This is useful for frequently changing content without server restarts. SOURCE: https://github.com/marimo-team/marimo/blob/main/docs/guides/deploying/programmatically.md#2025-04-19_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` server = ( marimo.create_asgi_app() .with_dynamic_directory(path="/dashboard", directory="./notebooks") ) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Loading and Displaying Dataframes with Pandas DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates how to load JSON data into a Pandas dataframe and display it using Marimo's rich viewer. SOURCE: https://github.com/marimo-team/marimo/blob/main/docs/guides/working_with_data/dataframes.md#2025-04-19_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` import pandas as pd df = pd.read_json( "https://raw.githubusercontent.com/vega/vega-datasets/master/data/cars.json" ) df ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Creating a Mermaid Flowchart Diagram in Marimo DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to create a Mermaid flowchart diagram in a Marimo notebook cell. It uses the mo.mermaid() function to render a directed graph that shows a decision tree for shopping choices. SOURCE: https://github.com/marimo-team/marimo/blob/main/docs/api/diagrams.md#2025-04-19_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` @app.cell def __(): mo.mermaid("graph TD\n A[Christmas] -->|Get money| B(Go shopping)\n B --> C{Let me think}\n C -->|One| D[Laptop]\n C -->|Two| E[iPhone]\n C -->|Three| F[Car]") return ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: RAG (Retrieval-Augmented Generation) Chat Model in Python DESCRIPTION: Implements a Retrieval-Augmented Generation model for the chat interface. This example shows how to enhance responses by finding relevant documents based on the user's question and using them as context for the LLM. SOURCE: https://github.com/marimo-team/marimo/blob/main/docs/api/inputs/chat.md#2025-04-19_snippet_3 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` import marimo as mo def rag_model(messages, config): question = messages[-1].content docs = find_relevant_docs(question) context = "\n".join(docs) prompt = f"Context: {context}\n\nQuestion: {question}\n\nAnswer:" response = query_llm(prompt, config) return response mo.ui.chat(rag_model) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Creating and Displaying Text Input in Marimo DESCRIPTION: This code snippet creates a text input field using mo.ui.text and displays it along with its current value. The text input is configured with a placeholder and label. The value of the input is shown dynamically using Markdown formatting. SOURCE: https://github.com/marimo-team/marimo/blob/main/docs/api/inputs/text.md#2025-04-19_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` @app.cell def __(): text = mo.ui.text(placeholder="Search...", label="Filter") return @app.cell def __(): mo.hstack([text, mo.md(f"Has value: {text.value}")]) return ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Accessing CLI Arguments in Marimo DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates how to access command-line arguments passed to a Marimo notebook using mo.cli_args. This allows for non-user-controllable argument passing to the notebook. SOURCE: https://github.com/marimo-team/marimo/blob/main/docs/api/query_params.md#2025-04-19_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` mo.cli_args ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Configuring Marimo via Script Metadata DESCRIPTION: Example of configuring Marimo settings using script metadata (PEP 723) directly in notebook files. SOURCE: https://github.com/marimo-team/marimo/blob/main/docs/guides/configuration/index.md#2025-04-19_snippet_3 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` # /// script # [tool.marimo.runtime] # auto_instantiate = false # on_cell_change = "lazy" # [tool.marimo.display] # theme = "dark" # cell_output = "below" # /// ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Creating Interactive Radio Buttons with Marimo DESCRIPTION: Creates a radio button group with three options and displays the selected value. SOURCE: https://github.com/marimo-team/marimo/blob/main/docs/api/inputs/radio.md#2025-04-19_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` @app.cell def __(): options = ["Apples", "Oranges", "Pears"] radio = mo.ui.radio(options=options) return @app.cell def __(): mo.hstack([radio, mo.md(f"Has value: {radio.value}")]) return ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Form Value Retrieval DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates how to access the submitted value from a Marimo form. SOURCE: https://github.com/marimo-team/marimo/blob/main/docs/recipes.md#2025-04-19_snippet_5 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` form.value ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Simple Echo Model with Chat UI in Python DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates a basic implementation of the chat UI with a simple echo model that returns the user's message. The example includes predefined prompts and configuration controls. SOURCE: https://github.com/marimo-team/marimo/blob/main/docs/api/inputs/chat.md#2025-04-19_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` @app.cell def __(): def simple_echo_model(messages, config): return f"You said: {messages[-1].content}" mo.ui.chat( simple_echo_model, prompts=["Hello", "How are you?"], show_configuration_controls=True ) return ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Loading and Displaying Dataframes with Polars DESCRIPTION: Shows how to load JSON data into a Polars dataframe and display it using Marimo's rich viewer. SOURCE: https://github.com/marimo-team/marimo/blob/main/docs/guides/working_with_data/dataframes.md#2025-04-19_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` import polars as pl df = pl.read_json( "https://raw.githubusercontent.com/vega/vega-datasets/master/data/cars.json" ) df ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Creating Interactive Scatter Plot with Marimo UI DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates reactive visualization using marimo UI components with matplotlib. Creates an interactive scatter plot that updates based on a slider input controlling the number of points. SOURCE: https://github.com/marimo-team/marimo/blob/main/tests/_server/ai/snapshots/chat_system_prompts.txt#2025-04-19_snippet_4 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` import marimo as mo import matplotlib.pyplot as plt import numpy as np # Create a slider and display it n_points = mo.ui.slider(10, 100, value=50, label="Number of points") n_points # Generate random data based on slider value x = np.random.rand(n_points.value) y = np.random.rand(n_points.value) plt.figure(figsize=(8, 6)) plt.scatter(x, y, alpha=0.7) plt.title(f"Scatter plot with {n_points.value} points") plt.xlabel("X axis") plt.ylabel("Y axis") plt.gca() ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Creating Reactive Altair Chart with marimo DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates setting up a reactive scatter plot using Altair and marimo with cars dataset. The plot shows horsepower vs miles per gallon, colored by origin. SOURCE: https://github.com/marimo-team/marimo/blob/main/docs/guides/working_with_data/plotting.md#2025-04-19_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` @app.cell async def __(): import pandas as pd import pyodide import micropip import json await micropip.install('altair') import altair as alt return @app.cell def __(): cars = pd.DataFrame(json.loads( pyodide.http.open_url('https://vega.github.io/vega-datasets/data/cars.json').read() )) chart = mo.ui.altair_chart(alt.Chart(cars).mark_point().encode( x='Horsepower', y='Miles_per_Gallon', color='Origin' )) return @app.cell def __(): mo.vstack([chart, mo.ui.table(chart.value)]) return ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Cerebras API Integration with OpenAI-Compatible Interface in Python DESCRIPTION: Shows how to use Cerebras API with Marimo's OpenAI-compatible interface. This example configures the base URL to point to the Cerebras API for accessing their LLama models. SOURCE: https://github.com/marimo-team/marimo/blob/main/docs/api/inputs/chat.md#2025-04-19_snippet_10 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` chatbot = mo.ui.chat( mo.ai.llm.openai( model="llama3.1-8b", api_key="csk-...", # insert your key here base_url="https://api.cerebras.ai/v1/", ), ) chatbot ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Accessing Request Data in marimo Notebooks with Python DESCRIPTION: Illustrates how to access request data within marimo notebooks using mo.app_meta().request. This is useful for implementing authentication or accessing user data. SOURCE: https://github.com/marimo-team/marimo/blob/main/docs/guides/deploying/programmatically.md#2025-04-19_snippet_3 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` import marimo as mo # Access request data in your notebook request = mo.app_meta().request if request and request.user and request.user["is_authenticated"]: content = f"Welcome {request.user['username']}!" else: content = "Please log in" mo.md(content) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Creating Markdown content in marimo DESCRIPTION: Example of how to create Markdown content in marimo using the mo.md() function, including interpolation of Python values. SOURCE: https://github.com/marimo-team/marimo/blob/main/docs/guides/coming_from/jupytext.md#2025-04-19_snippet_5 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` mo.md("...") mo.md(f"...") ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Basic Matplotlib Plot Example DESCRIPTION: Shows how to create and display a basic line plot using Matplotlib in marimo. This metadata is automatically tracked and updated when running notebooks in sandbox mode. The code uses the app.cell decorator to define a cell in the Marimo application. SOURCE: https://github.com/marimo-team/marimo/blob/main/docs/api/inputs/file_browser.md#2025-04-19_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` @app.cell def __(): mo.vstack([mo.ui.file_browser()]) return ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Accessing Query Parameters in marimo Web Apps (Python) DESCRIPTION: Illustrates how to use mo.query_params() to access URL query parameters in marimo web apps. This provides an alternative method for parameterization in web-based scenarios. SOURCE: https://github.com/marimo-team/marimo/blob/main/docs/guides/coming_from/papermill.md#2025-04-19_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` import marimo as mo # Access query params params = mo.query_params() param1 = params.get("param1", "default_value") ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Loading Static Notebooks in marimo with Python DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates how to load static notebooks from a directory using the with_app method. It loops through the directory contents and adds each notebook as a separate app. SOURCE: https://github.com/marimo-team/marimo/blob/main/docs/guides/deploying/programmatically.md#2025-04-19_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` from pathlib import Path server = marimo.create_asgi_app() app_names: list[str] = [] notebooks_dir = Path(__file__).parent / "notebooks" for filename in sorted(notebooks_dir.iterdir()): if filename.suffix == ".py": app_name = filename.stem server = server.with_app(path=f"/{app_name}", root=filename) app_names.append(app_name) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Generating Marimo Islands from Code Blocks in Python DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates how to generate Marimo islands programmatically using MarimoIslandGenerator. The code creates a simple app with two code blocks, handles Windows-specific event loop configuration, and saves the generated HTML to a file. SOURCE: https://github.com/marimo-team/marimo/blob/main/docs/guides/exporting.md#2025-04-19_snippet_8 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` import asyncio import sys from marimo import MarimoIslandGenerator if sys.platform == 'win32': asyncio.set_event_loop_policy(asyncio.WindowsSelectorEventLoopPolicy()) async def main(): generator = MarimoIslandGenerator() block1 = generator.add_code("import marimo as mo") block2 = generator.add_code("mo.md('Hello, islands!')") # Build the app app = await generator.build() # Render the app output = f""" {generator.render_head()} {block1.render(display_output=False)} {block2.render()} """ print(output) # Save the HTML to a file output_file = "output.html" with open(output_file, "w", encoding="utf-8") as f: f.write(output) if __name__ == '__main__': asyncio.run(main()) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: DataFrame Aliasing Across Cells DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates how to transform DataFrames across multiple cells using aliasing SOURCE: https://github.com/marimo-team/marimo/blob/main/docs/guides/coming_from/jupyter.md#2025-04-19_snippet_4 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` df = pd.DataFrame({"my_column": [1, 2]}) ``` LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` augmented_df = df augmented_df["another_column"] = [3, 4] ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Accessing Command Line Arguments in marimo (Python) DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates how to use mo.cli_args() to access command-line arguments passed to a marimo notebook. This allows for parameterization similar to Papermill's approach. The form adds a submit button, allowing the text area's value to be sent to Python only when submitted. SOURCE: https://github.com/marimo-team/marimo/blob/main/docs/guides/configuration/theming.md#2025-04-19_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: css CODE: ``` /* Load Inter from Google Fonts */ @import url('https://fonts.googleapis.com/css2?family=Inter:ital,opsz,wght@0,14..32,100..900;1,14..32,100..900&display=swap'); :root { --marimo-heading-font: 'Inter', sans-serif; } /* Increase paragraph font size and change color */ .paragraph { font-size: 1.2rem; color: light-dark(navy, pink); } ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Redirecting Stdout to Cell Output in Marimo (Python) DESCRIPTION: The marimo.redirect_stdout() function is used to capture and redirect stdout output to the cell's output in a Marimo notebook, useful for displaying print statements in app views. This example configures the base URL to connect to Groq's API for accessing their LLama models.
